intro: Sinapis geniculata, commonly known as garden mustard, is an annual herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like cabbages and broccoli. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender stems and alternate, pinnately lobed leaves. Its small yellow flowers are arranged in racemes and bloom from late spring to early summer. The plant produces slender, cylindrical pods that contain several seeds, which are often used in cooking and as a source of oil.
